Determine if ⃗F = ⟨x3, −y4⟩ is conservative or not. If conservative, ﬁnd a potential. Solution. Let F1 = x3, F2 = −y4. Then ∂1F2 = 0 = ∂2F1. This suggests that there Page 2 Math 317 Homework 2 Solutions Name is a potential of ⃗F . If ∇f = ⟨x3, −y4⟩, then ∂f ∂x = x3, ∂f ∂y = −y4. The ﬁrst equation implies f (x, y) = ∫ x3dx = 1 4x4 + g(y) for some function g(y). We use the second equation to determine g(y); ∂f ∂y = −y4 = g′(y) Hence, g(y) = ∫ −y4dy = − 1 5y5 + C, which yields f (x, y) = ∫ x3dx = 1 4x4 − 1 5y5 + C. 7. Determine if ⃗F = ⟨xey, ye x⟩ is conservative or not. If conservative, ﬁnd a potential. Solution. Let F1 = xey, F2 = ye x. Then ∂1F2 = ye x and ∂2F1 = xey so ∂1F2 ̸= ∂2F1. This shows that the given vector ﬁeld is not conservative, hence no such f may exist. 8. Suppose that a particle of mass M is ﬁxed at the origin (0, 0, 0) while a particle of mass m moves from (a, 0, 0) to (0, b, 0) along the ellipse (x/a) 2 + (y/b) 2 = 1 on the xy-plane under the gravitational force ⃗F(x, y, z) = − GM m |⟨x, y, z⟩|3 ⟨x, y, z⟩, where G is a constant. Compute the work done by the force. Solution. Method 1. Direct calculation. We can parametrize the curve by ⃗r (t) = ⟨a cos t, b sin t, 0⟩, 0 ≤ t ≤ π/2. Then ⃗F(⃗r (t)) · ⃗r ′(t) = − GM m (a2 cos2 t + b2 sin 2 t)3/2 ⟨a cos t, b sin t, 0⟩ · ⟨−a sin t, b cos t, 0⟩ therefore, the work is ∫ π/2 0 ⃗F(⃗r (t)) · ⃗r ′(t)dt = ∫ π/2 0 −GM m(b2 − a2) cos t sin t (a2 cos2 t + b2 sin 2 t)3/2 dt. From the substitution u = a2 cos 2 t + b2 sin 2 t, du = 2(b2 − a2) cos t sin t, Page 3 Math 317 Homework 2 Solutions Name we see that the above integral is equal to ∫ b2 a2 −GM m 2u3/2 du = GM mu−1/2        b2 a2 = GM m ( 1 |b| − 1 |a| ) . Method 2. We use that ⃗F is conservative. We attempt to ﬁnd a potential ϕ for ⃗F. From ∂xϕ = − GM mx (x2 + y2 + z2)3/2 , = F1 we get ϕ = GM m (x2 + y2 + z2)1/2 + f (y, z) for some function f . We can check that ∂y GM m (x2 + y2 + z2)1/2 = −(1/2)(2y) GM m (x2 + y2 + z2)3/2 = F2 and ∂z GM m (x2 + y2 + z2)1/2 = −(1/2)(2z) GM m (x2 + y2 + z2)3/2 = F3 and so ∇ GM m (x2 + y2 + z2)1/2 = ⃗F(x, y, z), which means that ϕ(x, y, z) = GM m (x2 + y2 + z2)1/2 is a potential. Thus, ∫ C ⃗F · d⃗r = ϕ(0, b, 0) − ϕ(a, 0, 0) = GM m ( 1 |b| − 1 |a| ) . Page 4
